title: How to set goals for myself - Quora

response.answer_text: The first mistake people make in working towards the goal, is setting the goal itself. Say you want to lose five pounds. Why? There are two basic parts to the goal. Let’s break it down. Firstly, why do you want to lose weight. Secondly, why five pounds? The time to achieve the goal wasn’t even mentioned. Whenever you set a goal, ask yourself, Who, What, When, Where, and Why. Who is the target of this goal? You. What is this goal? For you to lose weight. When do you want to accomplish this goal? Two weeks. Where are you going to accomplish this goal? You’re residing home state/country. How are you going to lose 5 pounds? People say, walking. Running. Working out. Great, those are methods. But HOW are you going to achieve this? What are the mechanics behind the goal? Your calories have to be less than what you burn. That means you have to eat less than the energy you use. Calculate how many calories you need to cut in order to get to that goal. The ways of losing 5 pounds are so vast. Understand that. The options we have available to us, sometimes hold us back and slow us down. But at least get a daily number, a weekly number, and a monthly number of a caloric deficit you have to accomplish in order to help you visualize not only the goal itself, but also to visualize the magnitude of the goal, the level of effort focus and discipline needed to be undertaken, in order to create the micro fractures to our identities that strengthen over time, which we call goals. And lastly, why? Why are you choosing to lose 5 lbs? Is it because you want to start losing weight because you’re overweight? Is it because you’re insecure about how you look? Is it because you’re unhealthy? Is it because someone made fun of you and you want to get back at them? If you can’t come up with a good reason as to why you want to do something, dig deeper and find meaning. Sometimes meaning and purpose can’t be described in words, which is completely fine, but you must understand why you want to do something, before you start making sacrifices to something that you may end up realizing seems stupid, senseless, or even irrelevant to your life. So there you have it. There you have a hopefully, stronger goal. Once you have your goal defined, approach your solutions, your options towards achieving your goal, the how of your goal, given the what of your goal, by keeping The Who, What, When, Where, Why questions in the back of your head when finding a solution. Add one more thing to ask yourself that we didn’t talk about earlier; ask yourself, if. What do I mean by that? When are you going to do your action in order to do goal y? 3 times a week 9pm every Monday Wednesday and Friday after work…. But if you have something Monday, what are you going to do (and if you don’t like that word do, and it makes you feel nervous, simply change do to change)? If you have something Friday night, what are you going to change? (If you don’t like either of those words, do or change, use then) If you are sick Wednesday, what then? Don’t stress yourself on all the ifs, changes, and thens. You can’t prepare for everything. However, you can prepare yourself for how you react. Do prepare yourself to react to change. Do prepare yourself to react to when something unforeseen and out of your control, or sometimes weakness, sets in. Prepare to deal with it. In other words, don’t only be prepared to accomplish your “How” portion of the goal, but also be prepared to quickly, and effectively deal with consequences. Consequences are what fail people. Adversity is what sends people running for the hills, never to come back. Working through your actions, and being prepared for dealing with pitfalls, consequences, setbacks, and adversity helps validate the quality of the goal you’ve created for yourself. On the surface, achieving goals isn’t one thing. Sometimes it’s a race.  Sometimes it’s a marathon.  Sometimes it’s an obstacle course.  And every now and then, sometimes, it’s even a walk in the park.  But at its core, it is always one thing,  and that is a fight against yourself.

Make it as simple as possible. Here’s how I do it — I set ONE main goal for a single day. Why? To make it easy to focus, and make it impossible to ignore. What do I actually do? I ask myself the following question every morning when I wake up: What is the ONE thing I am committed to completing today? Let me explain. What are some examples of “the ONE thing”? The one thing refers to a single task, a single activity, or a single project that I promise myself I will finish completely by the end of that day. It can be: Writing. An outline for an article I'm preparing, a plan of work for the upcoming week, a blog post, a letter to a friend I want to reach out to today.Completing tasks. Proofreading my work before publishing, cleaning up and organizing my inbox, preparing for a meeting or presentation, sending off an email with a completed task or project.Making progress on a project. Reading one chapter from a book and taking notes, doing preliminary research on a work topic at the library, listening to a 30-minute podcast on the commute, finishing homework due the next day.Personal development. Doing a short workout routine for 20 minutes, creating a strategy on how to build a new habit in the following month, scheduling 30 minutes in the evening to read my book.What are steps to identify your ONE thing? Write it down. Take a large sheet of paper and write the question in big bold letters with a thick marker.Hang it on your bedroom or bathroom wall. The point is that you make it easy to see every day.Ask the question out loud. You can do this as you are brushing your teeth, stepping into the shower, or getting dressed.Take a few moments to think about your answer. Ask yourself what’s on your agenda for the day, then pick one thing that has top priority for you and give an answer out loud to yourself.Keep your answer top of mind as you go about your day. This will help you to avoid getting distracted by other things that might take you away from what’s important to you.Start working on your one thing early. Your brain is more capable of tackling analytical and complex problem-solving tasks in the first few hours of the day.How does this practice improve your goal-setting habits? It simplifies your decision-making. Our brain functions so much better when it’s not bogged down with evaluating priorities, considering the pros and cons, and going back and forth on small things that can be a huge waste of time. If you have to make a choice on something, you should do it as early in the day as possible.It taps into your willpower when it's at its peak. We all have only a finite amount of willpower that we can distribute on what we want to do each day. It’s not negotiable. So, in order to maximize it, it’s best to have a plan of attack early in the morning so you know exactly where to focus your energies, and why.It encourages strategic thinking. In order to accomplish something that is of value to you, you’ll need to assess what needs to be completed on that particular day. Maybe you know there’s a deadline at work for one project that you can’t delay any longer, and asking the question will push to you think about what you need to do right now.It keeps you focused. Once you ask the question, you’re much less likely to give a frivolous answer, and instead you’ll push yourself to be honest about what’s top priority for you. Maybe you didn’t give it a lot of time or maybe you procrastinated, but that’s over now. It’s time for action.It boosts critical-thinking skills. By posing the question to yourself, you’ll come up with a few scenarios of what the answer might be. Maybe it’s starting a difficult task, or tackling a problem you haven’t been able to solve for days. Either way, you’ll need to assess your why and how before you give an answer, which should keep your brain alert and focused so it can operate optimally the rest of the day.
